Award.AwardTitle: Influence of Local Cytoskeletal Plasticity on Neuronal Cell Mechanics

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to investigate fundamental relationships between force transmission in neurons and the neuronal cytoskeleton, an interconnected filamentous structural network that plays a key role in determining neuronal morphology and stability. In particular, the role of tensile loading (stretch) on the regional deformation of the cytoskeleton will be investigated. The study will involve a multidisciplinary approach, integrating cell biomechanics, high-resolution imaging, and image processing. Key outcomes include the definition of spatial and temporal distributions of tension within unstretched and stretched axons, the characterization of spatial and temporal changes in cytoskeletal mobility and stability in response to tension, and the elaboration of a role for cytoskeletal filaments and crosslinking molecular motor proteins in guiding cytoskeletal remodeling.

If successful, this work will have significant implications for understanding structure-function relationships in the developing and mature peripheral nervous system, including potential biological and chemical signaling pathways triggered by local deformation. In the long-term, this work holds the potential to provide a mechanistic basis for the progression of neurological conditions such as carpal tunnel syndrome, or enhancing nerve repair. It is also expected that general principles identified from work in neurons will facilitate the understanding of cytoskeletal plasticity in non-neuronal cells. The educational and outreach plans focus on the integration of research results into two bioengineering courses based on cell physiology, as well as providing multidisciplinary research training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students from backgrounds in both engineering and biological sciences. Additionally, a summer outreach program will expose middle and high school students from backgrounds underrepresented in science and engineering to career options in bioengineering, introduce them to research methodology and scientific writing, and provide them with access to state-of-the-art laboratory facilities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Neurons are wire-like cells that communicate electrically. In the central nervous system (CNS), neurons form networks to control subconscious processes such as breathing and heartbeat. CNS neurons also communicate with neurons in the peripheral nervous system (PNS), to enable movement, sensation, and autonomic function. In addition to responding to electrical signals, though not typically thought of as mechanical cells, neurons are also highly responsive to changes in their mechanical environment. In the central nervous system, neurons must accommodate changes in pressure during normal ebbs and flows in intracranial pressure. In the peripheral nervous system, neurons that span the joints of our limbs and spine must bear the stretching and twisting that occurs during movement. Though too much of a load can damage neurons, beyond these “normal” levels of mechanical loading, neurons can actually accelerate their growth in response to sustained moderate deformation.

There are many gaps in our knowledge of how neurons accommodate and respond to mechanical loads, thus limiting our ability to prevent mechanisms of mechanical failure in neurons as well as exploit mechanical loading for neuro-regenerative applications. We hypothesized that the structural scaffolding of neurons – the cytoskeleton – was likely to play a key role in responding to loading. Thus, through this funded project, we took a closer look at how the cytoskeleton immediately responded and also subsequently remodeled in response to loading. We examined two types of loading – tensile loading (stretch) and osmotic loading (increased or decreased pressure). There were four key scientific outcomes from our work that have advanced our understanding of neuronal mechanobiology. (1) We developed two new technologies to stretch single neurons, while simultaneously imaging cytoskeletal movement within these neurons in response to stretch. (2) We discovered that rigid elements of the cytoskeleton slide relative to each other in response to stretch, likely through the activity of motor proteins that attach to and actively walk along the cytoskeleton. Cytoskeletal elements move rapidly initially after stretch, and then more slowly or not at all if stretch is maintained. (3) We discovered that movement of the actin filaments, one of the three major components of the cytoskeleton (microtubules and neurofilaments being the other), is directly dependent on the integrity and stability of the actin-myosin network as well as the microtubule network. This finding supports biochemical evidence that elements of the cytoskeleton are interdependent on each other for maintaining neuronal structure. (4) We discovered that the actin network plays two separate roles in response to osmotic loading, both through interactions with myosin motors, to form a contractile network that counteracts intraneuronal pressure as well as more passively, to absorb loads in the absence of myosin. Together, these findings show that the neuronal cytoskeleton is a flexible, dynamic structure that actively, rather than passively, responds to mechanical loading. The next step in our research is to understand how mechanical loading and cytoskeletal dynamics dictate other cellular functions, including the synthesis of new proteins or intracellular movement of existing proteins, which are required to maintain function or sustain growth.

In terms of broader impacts, the funded project also contributed to the laboratory training of three graduate students, seven undergraduates, and two high school students.
